[[Hershey Bears]] ([[American Hockey League|AHL]]) | name1 = | dates1 = | name2 = | dates2 = | note = |reg_season_titles = [[1996â97 ECHL season|1996–97]] |division_titles = [[1994â95 ECHL season|1994–95]], [[1996â97 ECHL season|1996–97]], [[1997â98 ECHL season|1997–98]], [[2000â01 ECHL season|2000–01]] |conf_titles = [[1996â97 ECHL season|1996–97]], [[2000â01 ECHL season|2000–01]], [[2008â09 ECHL season|2008–09]] |kelly_cups = [[1996â97 ECHL season|1996–97]], [[2000â01 ECHL season|2000–01]], [[2008â09 ECHL season|2008–09]] }} The '''South Carolina Stingrays''' are a professional [[minor league]] [[ice hockey]] team based in [[North Charleston, South Carolina|North Charleston]], [[South Carolina]]. The Stingrays play in the South Division of the [[ECHL]]'s Eastern Conference. They play their home games at the [[North Charleston Coliseum]]. The Carolina Ice Palace, also located in North Charleston, serves as a practice facility and backup arena for the Stingrays. Established in 1993, the team has been owned by a conglomerate of local business owners since 1995. Since 2004, the team has been affiliated with the [[Washington Capitals]] of the [[National Hockey League]] and the [[Hershey Bears]] of the [[American Hockey League]]. The Stingrays are the first professional ice hockey team established in the state of South Carolina. With the relocation of the [[Johnstown Chiefs]] to [[Greenville Road Warriors|Greenville]], South Carolina in [[2010–11 ECHL season|2010]], the Stingrays became the oldest continuously operational ECHL franchise to remain in its founding city (the [[Wheeling Nailers]], while an older franchise, originated in [[Winston-Salem, North Carolina]] as the [[Carolina Thunderbirds]] in 1988). The Stingrays have finished with the [[Brabham Cup|best record]] in the ECHL once, and qualified for the playoffs for every season except [[2006–07 ECHL season|one]]. With [[Kelly Cup]] championships in [[1996–97 ECHL season|1997]], [[2000–01 ECHL season|2001]] and [[2008–09 ECHL season|2009]], the Stingrays are tied with the [[Hampton Roads Admirals]] for the record for most league championships. Twenty-two former Stingrays players have gone on to play in the [[National Hockey League]] with one ([[Rich Peverley]]) winning the [[Stanley Cup]] with the [[Boston Bruins]] in [[2010–11 NHL season|2011]]. The team developed a large fan base rapidly following its inception. During its first season ([[1993–94 ECHL season|1993–94]]) the team boasted an average of 9,151 fans a game—one of the largest crowds in minor league hockey.{{cite book|first=Jon C.|last=Stott|title=Hockey Night in Dixie: Minor Pro Hockey in the American South|year=2006|publisher=Heritage House Publishing Company Ltd.|page=70|isbn=1894974212}} Recent years have seen a downward trend in attendance. During the [[2010-11 ECHL season|2010–11 season]], the Stingrays averaged approximately 3,400 fans per game.{{cite web|title=Leaguestat Daily Report for the ECHL|publisher=[[ECHL]]|url=http://www.echl.com/files/201011ECHL.pdf|date=2011-04-03|accessdate=2011-07-13}} ==Team history== [[File:Original Stingrays.PNG|thumb|left|alt=Original South Carolina Stingrays logo: Red silhouette of the state of South Carolina with a white stingray superimposed. Stingray's blue tail is curled around a white hockey stick, with the words "South Carolina Stingrays" in black.|Original Stingrays logo, used 1993–2000; revived for throwback third jerseys in 2011–12.]] ===Birth of a franchise=== The South Carolina Stingrays were founded in 1993 as an expansion team in the [[ECHL|East Coast Hockey League]] (ECHL). Its management team included Joseph Scanlon as president/CEO and retired [[National Hockey League]] (NHL) player [[Rick Vaive]] as head coach. The team was originally to be designated the South Carolina Sharks,S. 324 (1993-02-02). [http://www.scstatehouse.gov/sess110_1993-1994/sj93/19930202.htm "A concurrent resolution to congratulate and welcome the South Carolina Sharks on their establishment as the first professional hockey team in South Carolina"]. [[South Carolina Senate]]. Retrieved 2010-11-09. but eventually settled on the Stingrays name to avoid a copyright dispute with the NHL's [[San Jose Sharks]].Sapakoff, Gene (1994-12-23). [http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch94/1294/arc122394780.shtml "A team that the Stingrays can hate"]. ''[[Post and Courier]]''. Retrieved 2010-11-09. In late 1993, Scanlon filed a lawsuit in a Canadian court in an attempt to wrest control of the team from its ownership group. He was replaced as president and CEO by retired NHL [[Hockey Hall of Fame|Hall of Famer]] [[Marcel Dionne]] in December of that year. Dionne was accused of assault in February 1994 by Lynn Bernstein, an ally of Scanlon, over a dispute regarding the removal of advertising signs at the [[North Charleston Coliseum]], but was later acquitted.MacDougall, David (1994-12-09). [http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch94/1294/arc120995802.shtml "Stingrays chief acquitted in assault"]. ''[[Post and Courier]]''. Retrieved 2010-11-09. Following dismissal of Scanlon's lawsuit, the ECHL Board of Governors ended the power struggle when it approved the sale of the franchise from its Canadian ownership group to a local investment group led by Edwin Pearlstine, owner of Pearlstine Distribution, the local [[Budweiser]] distributor. The group also included [[Jerry Zucker (businessman)|Jerry]] and [[Anita Zucker]], Harvey Nathan and Lynn Bernstein (owners of local restaurant Nathan's Deli), and the Greenwald family of Seabrook Island. Dionne remained the franchise's president and CEO.Namm, Keith (1995-03-21). [http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch95/0395/arc0321101957.shtml "Local group approved to buy 'Rays HOMETOWN HOCKEY"]. ''[[Post and Courier]]''. Retrieved 2010-11-04. In early 1995, along with [[Charlotte Checkers (ECHL)|Charlotte]], [[Greensboro Monarchs|Greensboro]], and [[Hampton Roads Admirals|Hamptons Roads]], the team was offered an expansion spot by the [[American Hockey League]] (AHL), the intermediate level between the ECHL and the NHL.Namm, Keith (1995-03-08). [http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch95/0395/arc0308102673.shtml "AHL has eye on Stingrays"]. ''[[Post and Courier]]''. Retrieved 2010-11-04. However, team management decided to remain in the ECHL, citing a desire to retain the level of affordability for the team's fans.Namm, Keith (1995-03-21). [http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch95/0395/arc0321101270.shtml "Stingrays will stay in ECHL"]. ''[[Post and Courier]]''. Retrieved 2010-11-04. The other three franchises have since accepted AHL offers, becoming the [[Charlotte Checkers (AHL)|Charlotte Checkers]], [[Carolina Monarchs]], and [[Norfolk Admirals]], respectively. Later that year, Dionne left the Stingrays organization. Vaive succeeded Dionne as director of hockey operations while retaining his head coaching position, thus giving him more control over personnel decisions.Hartsell, Jeff (1995-06-08). [http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch95/0695/arc0608107634.shtml "Rays' Dionne gone VAIVE TAKES OVER"]. ''[[Post and Courier]]''. Retrieved 2010-11-04. ===Rick Vaive era (1993–98)=== The Stingrays finished sixth in the East Division in their inaugural season and were eliminated in the first round of the 1993–94 playoffs by the [[Hampton Roads Admirals]].Namm, Keith (1994-12-07). [http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch94/1294/arc120795659.shtml "Stingrays take on familiar foe tonight"]. ''[[Post and Courier]]''. Retrieved 2011-07-30. Despite their early playoff exit, the team had several significant achievements during their inaugural season. Center [[Sylvain Fleury]] finished tenth among league skaters for total points with 95 points in 68 games played and scored a league season-high five goals in an 11–6 victory over the Greensboro Monarchs on December 26.{{cite web | title = East Coast Hockey League final official statistics — 1993–1994 | publisher = [[ECHL]] | url = http://echl.com/files/ECHL9394.pdf | accessdate = October 17, 2011}} Left winger [[Andy Bezeau]] was second in the league in penalty minutes, accumulating 352 minutes in 36 games (29 fewer games than [[Trevor Buchanan]], the league leader with 422 minutes).{{cite web | title = 1993–94 ECHL league leaders | publisher = hockeydb.com | url = http://www.hockeydb.com/ihdb/stats/top_league.php?lid=echl1989&sid=1994&leaguenm=ECHL | accessdate = October 17, 2011}} From January 19–28, the Stingrays went on a six-game winning streak wherein they totaled 43 goals for and only 13 goals against, including two games in which they scored 11 goals each against their opponents (one of which, against the [[Huntington Blizzard]], had 67 shots on goal by the Stingrays).{{cite web | title = 1993–94 South Carolina Stingrays results and schedule | publisher = hockeydb.com | url = http://www.hockeydb.com/ihdb/stats/team_results.php?tid=000269&sid=1994 | accessdate = October 17, 2011}} The team led the league in attendance with an average of 9,151 fans per game. In 1994–95, the team took the top spot in the Southern Division but were knocked out in the second round by the [[Nashville Knights]].Namm, Keith (1995-04-09). [http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch95/0495/arc0409103833.shtml "Good Knight to Stingrays' season"]. ''[[Post and Courier]]''. Retrieved 2011-07-30. They set the current league record for the longest home winning streak that season with 18 victories at home between December 23, 1994, and March 19, 1995. Goaltender [[Steve Shields (ice hockey)|Steve Shields]] finished second in the league with a 2.68 [[goals against average]] (GAA), a 0.912 save percentage and 11 wins in 17 games, while [[Jason Fitzsimmons]] (who later served as assistant and then head coach for the Stingrays) finished sixth in the league with a 2.97 GAA, a 0.901 save percentage and 24 wins in 37 games played. The Stingrays drew the highest attendance in the league, averaging 8,589 fans per game.{{cite web | title = East Coast Hockey League final official statistics — 1994–1995 | publisher = [[ECHL]] | url = http://echl.com/files/ECHL9495.pdf | accessdate = October 17, 2011}} The Stingrays returned to the East Division in 1995–96 and finished third in the regular season, falling in the second round of the playoffs to the Charlotte Checkers.Namm, Keith (1996-04-14). [http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch96/0496/arc0414127522.shtml "Checkers eliminate Stingrays"]. ''[[Post and Courier]]''. Retrieved 2011-07-30. They posted an 8-game road winning streak that season, lasting from December 15 until January 13, in which they accumulated 48 goals and surrendered 27 goals against. Defenseman [[Scott Boston]] finished sixth among top-scoring defensemen in the league with 58 total points in 67 games. The Stingrays fell to second place in league attendance with an average 7,447 fans per game. The [[Alaska Aces (ECHL)|Alaska Aces]] (2006, 2011) and the [[Cincinnati Cyclones]] (2008) later accomplished this feat. Forwards [[Ed Courtenay]] and [[Mike Ross (ice hockey)|Mike Ross]] tied for the highest total points in the league, each with 110 points in combined goals and assists. Forward [[Dave Seitz]] finished seventh with 97 total points.{{cite web | title = East Coast Hockey League final official statistics — 1996–1997 | publisher = [[ECHL]] | url = http://echl.com/files/ECHL9697.pdf | accessdate = October 17, 2011}} Ross was also named the league's [[Most Valuable Player]] (MVP), the only member of the Stingrays to receive this distinction through the 2010–11 season.{{cite web | title = CCM U+ Most Vaulable Player award winners | publisher = [[ECHL]] | url = http://www.echl.com/reebok-most-valuable-player-award-winners-p144413 | accessdate = October 17, 2011}} Goaltender Jason Fitzsimmons was selected as the Kelly Cup playoffs MVP.{{cite web | title = Playoff MVP winners | publisher = [[ECHL]] | url = http://www.echl.com/playoff-mvp-winners-p144414 | accessdate = October 17, 2011}} Fitzsimmons totaled 13 wins in 17 playoff games and achieved a 3.38 GAA with a 0.903 save percentage. Following their Kelly Cup victory, ECHL management accused the franchise of circumventing the league's salary cap by colluding with the city of [[North Charleston]] to funnel money through a city-run youth hockey program to provide payouts to players. After two months of investigation by the league, the Stingrays were assessed a US$50,000 fine, and Vaive was suspended for the first six games of the 1997–98 season. The [[Internal Revenue Service]] determined that no state or federal tax laws were broken, but the incident sparked a re-evaluation by the ECHL of the teams' salary caps.Sapakoff, Gene (1997-09-05). [http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch97/0997/arc0905171379.shtml "Stingrays fined $50,000, ECHL executives feel $50,000 fine too lenient"]. ''[[Post and Courier]]''. Retrieved 2010-11-04. Early in the 1997–98 season, the Stingrays won a league-high 12 consecutive home games from October 24 to January 2 in which they accumulated 52 goals and allowed 24 goals against. Defenseman [[Chris Hynnes]] finished the regular season first in goals (19) and fourth in total points (58) among league defensemen. Goaltender [[Cory Cadden]] finished seventh in the league with a 2.85 GAA, a 0.907 save percentage and 30 wins in 45 games.{{cite web | title = East Coast Hockey League final official statistics — 1997–1998 | publisher = [[ECHL]] | url = http://echl.com/files/ECHL9798.pdf | accessdate = October 17, 2011}} The team finished at the top of the Southeast Division, but fell in a first round playoff series against their new in-state rival, the [[Pee Dee Pride]]. The Pride advanced after coming back from a three goal deficit to win the fifth game of a best of five series in overtime. Vaive reported after the fact that replays indicated that the game-tying goal was invalid but the referee missed the call, resulting in the overtime period and the Stingrays' eventual defeat.Namm, Keith (1998-04-09), [http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch98/0498/arc0409187823.shtml "Pride's goal in OT eliminates Stingrays"]. ''[[Post and Courier]]''. Retrieved 2011-07-30. ===Rick Adduono era (1998–2002)=== For the 1998–99 season, Vaive accepted the head coaching position with the AHL's [[Saint John Flames]]. His assistant coach, [[Rick Adduono]], was tapped to take over as Vaive's replacement as head coach and general manager.Miller, Andrew (1998-09-04). [http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch98/0998/arc0904202742.shtml "Rays name coach"]. ''[[Post and Courier]]''. Retrieved 2010-11-04. Former Stingrays [[goaltender]] [[Jason Fitzsimmons]] was named assistant coach in Adduono's place.Staff reports (1998-10-07). [http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch98/1098/arc1007207067.shtml "Fitzsimmons named assistant"]. ''[[Post and Courier]]''. Retrieved 2010-11-04. The Stingrays finished third in the Southeast Division, with defenseman [[Brad Dexter (ice hockey)|Brad Dexter]] third in the league for top-scoring defensemen with 55 points in 19 goals and 26 assists. Forward [[Dave Seitz]] led the league in game-winning goals with 11, while goaltender [[Jody Lehman]] finished seventh among league netminders with a 2.72 GAA and a 0.916 save percentage.{{cite web | title = East Coast Hockey League final official statistics — 1998–1999 | publisher = [[ECHL]] | url = http://echl.com/files/ECHL9899.pdf | accessdate = October 29, 2011}} After receiving a first-round bye for the playoffs, the Stingrays fell in a second-round 3-game shutout to the [[Mississippi Sea Wolves]]. The final game was decided in overtime and ran to 110 minutes and 37 seconds, making it the fifth-longest overtime playoff game in league history as of the 2010–11 season. The team finished fourth in the Southeast Division in 1999–2000. Brad Dexter again finished third in total points among league defensemen with 66. He placed first among defensemen and fifth among all skaters for assists with 59.{{cite web | title = East Coast Hockey League final official statistics — 1999–2000 | publisher = [[ECHL]] | url = http://echl.com/files/ECHL9900.pdf | accessdate = October 29, 2011}} The Stingrays set the league postseason record for most goals by one team in a two-game series with 11 goals in their two game shutout of the [[Baton Rouge Kingfish]] in the preliminary round of the playoffs. The team eliminated in-state rivals [[Pee Dee Pride]] three games to two to advance to the second round, where they were shut out in three games by the [[Louisiana IceGators]]. The Stingrays took the league championship again in 2001, defeating the then-[[Trenton Titans]] in five games.Miller, Andrew (2001-05-28). [http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch01/0501/arc0528291852.shtml "ICE PRINCES Stingrays claim 2nd ECHL title"]. ''[[Post and Courier]]''. Retrieved 2010-11-04. ===Jason Fitzsimmons era (2002–07)=== After failing to advance to the first round of the ECHL playoffs the next season by losing a "play-in" game in the 2001–02 season to the [[Florida Everblades]] in their practice facility (a concert at the Coliseum forced the move), Adduono was released from his contract and was replaced by Fitzsimmons.Miller, Andrew (2002-04-24). [http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch02/0402/arc0424563656.shtml "STINGRAYS FIRE COACH ADDUONO"]. ''[[Post and Courier]]''. Retrieved 2010-11-04. [[Jared Bednar]], another longtime Stingray, was made assistant coach later.Miller, Andrew (2002-05-24). [http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch02/0502/arc0524603890.shtml "Bednar steps into role of Stingrays' assistant"]. ''[[Post and Courier]]''. Retrieved 2010-11-04. Despite a long-standing association with the [[Buffalo Sabres]], the Stingrays broke away just before the 2001–02 season and played three seasons as an independent team. For the 2004–05 season, the team agreed to an affiliation with the [[Washington Capitals]], which they have maintained to the present day.Miller, Andrew (2004-08-12). [http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch04/0804/arc08121865624.shtml "Rays sign affiliation deal with Capitals"]. ''[[Post and Courier]]''. Retrieved 2010-11-04. From 2003–06, the Stingrays experienced another run of first and second round playoff defeats. Despite a strong second place finish in the Southeast Division in 2003, they fell three games to one to the Pee Dee Pride in the first round of the playoffs.Miller, Andrew (2003-04-08). [http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch03/0403/arc04081096204.shtml "Pee Dee finished Stingrays"]. ''[[Post and Courier]]''. Retrieved 2011-07-30. The Stingrays moved to the Southern Division for the 2003–04 season, finishing fourth in the regular season and advancing to the second round of the playoffs, where they were swept three games to none by the Florida Everblades, the final game a crushing 8–2 loss.Miller, Andrew (2004-04-23). [http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch04/0404/arc04231697471.shtml "Rays swept away"]. ''[[Post and Courier]]''. Retrieved 2011-07-30. For the 2004–05 season, the Stingrays returned to the East Division, where they finished second in the regular season. They were defeated three games to one in the first round of the playoffs, again to the Everblades.Miller, Andrew (2005-04-19). [http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch05/0405/arc04192274855.shtml "Stingrays stung in OT"]. ''[[Post and Courier]]''. Retrieved 2011-07-30. The 2005–06 season marked the Stingrays' first year in the newly designated South Division, in which they have remained to the present day. They finished fourth in the regular season and defeated the Charlotte Checkers in the Kelly Cup playoffs' first round, only to fall in a second round sweep—three games to none—by the [[Gwinnett Gladiators]].Miller, Andrew (2006-04-20). [http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch06/0406/arc04203051400.shtml "Stingrays on ice"]. ''[[Post and Courier]]''. Retrieved 2011-07-30. [[File:Stingrays vs Checkers 4-17-09.jpg|thumb|right|alt=South Carolina Stingrays and Charlotte Checkers battle for control of the puck at a center ice face off; Charlotte Checkers at South Carolina Stingrays, April 17, 2009.|The Stingrays battle the Charlotte Checkers for control of the puck during the first round of the [[2009 Kelly Cup playoffs]].]] ===Jared Bednar era (2007–09)=== After failing to qualify for the ECHL playoffs for the only time in franchise history during the 2006–07 season,Miller, Andrew (2007-04-07). [http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch07/0407/arc04074284999.shtml "Stingrays miss playoffs for first time in 14 years"]. ''[[Post and Courier]]''. Retrieved 2010-11-04. Fitzsimmons resigned, and was assigned by the Washington Capitals as a scout.Miller, Andrew (2007-04-17). [http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch07/0407/arc04174330687.shtml "Stingrays coach to resign"]. ''[[Post and Courier]]''. Retrieved 2010-11-04. Bednar took over as head coach, with [[Cail MacLean]], who had been the [[Captain (ice hockey)|captain]] for the Stingrays, as a part-time assistant while completing his studies at The Citadel.Miller, Andrew (2007-04-27). [http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch07/0407/arc04274382761.shtml "Rays choose Bednar"]. ''[[Post and Courier]]''. Retrieved 2010-11-04. Bednar took the Stingrays to the Kelly Cup playoffs for both of his seasons as head coach. In the 2007–08 season, the Stingrays advanced to the American Conference finals, losing 4–1 to the Cincinnati Cyclones in a suspense-filled series wherein three games (including the final) were decided in overtime.Miller, Andrew (2008-05-21). [http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch08/0508/arc05216287875.shtml "A lot for us to be proud of"]. ''[[Post and Courier]]''. Retrieved 2011-07-26. The Stingrays built on this momentum in the 2008–09 season, sweeping Cincinnati 4–0 in the conference finals and winning the Kelly Cup on the road in the culmination of a 4–3 series with the Alaska Aces.Miller, Andrew (2009-6-07). [http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch09/0609/arc06078086785.shtml "Rays of Joy"]. ''[[Post and Courier]]''. Retrieved 2010-11-04. Bednar resigned shortly thereafter, joining the [[Calgary Flames]]' system in [[Abbotsford Heat|Abbotsford]] as assistant coach,Miller, Andrew (2009-07-01). [http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch09/0709/arc07018200011.shtml "Bednar takes job in AHL"]. ''[[Post and Courier]]''. Retrieved 2010-11-04. and later earned his first AHL head coaching assignment with the [[St. Louis Blues (ice hockey)|St. Louis Blues]]' farm club in [[Peoria Rivermen|Peoria]] for 2010–11.Miller, Andrew (2010-06-07). [http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch10/0610/arc061710102345.shtml "Bednar gets reins at Peoria of AHL"]. ''[[Post and Courier]]''. Retrieved 2010-11-04. MacLean was named head coach, with the assistant coach position becoming vacant.Miller, Andrew (2009-07-02). [http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch09/0709/arc07028204947.shtml "Reins change hands"]. ''[[Post and Courier]]''. Retrieved 2010-11-04. Building on their championship success, many players on the 2009 Kelly Cup team were called up to the American Hockey League during the 2009–10 season. Six players from the 2009 team played in the [[2010 Calder Cup Playoffs#Calder Cup Finals|2010 Calder Cup Championship]] - five for the victorious [[Hershey Bears]], and one for the runner-up [[Texas Stars]]. ===Cail MacLean era (2009–11)=== This success, however, was short-lived. Despite a strong regular season showing that left the Stingrays tied with the South Division (and American Conference) leader Charlotte Checkers and North Division leader [[Kalamazoo Wings]], the team ended up fourth seed in the [[2010 Kelly Cup playoffs]], falling three games to two in the first round to the eventual champions, the Cincinnati Cyclones. For a team that was the first in the ECHL to reach 30 wins that season (in a 5–3 victory over the [[Reading Royals]] in front of a record sellout crowd of 10,570),Miller, Andrew (2010-01-24). [http://www.postandcourier.com/news/2010/jan/24/stingrays-treated-royalty-10570-fans/ "Stingrays treated like royalty from 10,570 fans"]. ''[[Post and Courier]]''. Retrieved 2011-07-21. the first round defeat was disappointing to players and fans alike.Miller, Andrew (2010-09-25).[http://www.postandcourier.com/news/2010/sep/25/scherer-returns-to-chase-another-title/ "Scherer returns to chase another title"]. ''[[Post and Courier]]''. Retrieved 2011-07-21. [[File:Stingrays vs Cyclones 3-7-10.jpg|thumb|left|alt=Gregg Johnson faces off against Barret Ehgoetz; Cincinnati Cyclones at South Carolina Stingrays, March 7, 2010.|[[Gregg Johnson]] faces off against [[Barret Ehgoetz]] of the Cincinnati Cyclones during the 2009–10 season.]] Former Stingray [[Rob Concannon]] was picked to succeed Darren Abbott as team president at the end of the 2009–10 season.Miller, Andrew (2010-03-27).[http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch10/0310/arc03279629581.shtml "Concannon named Stingrays president"]. ''[[Post and Courier]]''. Retrieved 2010-11-04. In August 2010, the Stingrays announced that former [[Forward (ice hockey)|forward]] [[Spencer Carbery]] had been named the team's assistant coach.Miller, Andrew (2010-09-01). [http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch10/0910/arc090110495937.shtml "Ex-Stingray Carbery now coach"]. ''[[Post and Courier]]''. Retrieved 2010-11-04. With the return of forwards [[Maxime Lacroix]] and [[Pierre-Luc O'Brien]]—both of whom played a vital role in the 2009 Kelly Cup championship—the team looked to build momentum towards a fourth championship.Miller, Andrew (2010-10-05). [http://www.postandcourier.com/news/2010/nov/05/rays-look-to-replicate-09-run/ "Stingrays look to replicate '09 run"]. ''[[Post and Courier]]''. Retrieved 2011-07-21. However, injuries, call-ups, and ultimately inconsistent play on the ice resulted in another disappointing first round playoff loss, this time to the [[Wheeling Nailers]].Miller, Andrew (2011-04-12). [http://www.postandcourier.com/news/2011/apr/12/consistently-inconsistent/ "Consistently inconsistent: MacLean believes team has unfinished business after up-and-down season"]. ''[[Post and Courier]]''. Retrieved 2011-07-21. A bright spot in the midst of the team's disappointing seasons came from a terrible tragedy. In February 2010, former Stingrays goaltender [[Kirk Daubenspeck]]—who played for the team from 1999 to 2006 and was part of the Kelly Cup championship team in 2001—was in a near-fatal car accident that resulted in a traumatic brain injury that left him in a coma for six days.Miller, Andrew (2011-04-23). [http://www.postandcourier.com/news/2011/apr/23/alumni-game-to-raise-money-for-daubenspeck/ "Alumni game to raise money for Daubenspeck"]. ''[[Post and Courier]]''. Retrieved 2011-07-21. Friends, family members and former teammates from the Stingrays, the Hershey Bears, [[Culver Military Academy]] and the [[University of Wisconsin]] (Daubenspeck's alma maters) banded together to raise money to help defray the extensive medical bills. The team sold t-shirts bearing Daubenspeck's name and number (29) at the season's remaining home games.Staff report (2011-02-22). [http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch11/0211/arc022211477187.shtml "Stingrays fundraising for Daubenspeck"]. ''[[Post and Courier]]''. Retrieved 2011-07-21. In April 2010, current and former Stingrays donned their skates and took to the ice for the team's first ever alumni game, held to benefit the Daubenspeck family. The event (held at the Carolina Ice Palace) drew a capacity crowd of over 700 and raised over $20,000 in ticket sales and from a post-game jersey auction. Daubenspeck and his family were in attendance, and Daubenspeck dropped the game's ceremonial first puck.Press release (2011-04-25). [http://stingrayshockey.com/news/teamnews/index.html?article_id=1806 "Alumni game raises over $20,000 for Daubenspeck"]. South Carolina Stingrays. Retrieved 2011-07-21. ===Spencer Carbery era (2011–present)=== The team announced in July 2011 that head coach Cail MacLean had accepted the assistant coaching position for the AHL's Abbotsford Heat, a spot previously held by former Stingrays head coach Jared Bednar.Press release (2011-07-21). [http://echl.com/stingrays-maclean-accepts-ahl-position-p171855 "Stingrays' MacLean accepts AHL position"]. [[ECHL]]. Retrieved 2011-07-21. Assistant coach Spencer Carbery was tapped to take MacLean's place, making him the team's sixth head coach and the youngest head coach in the league.Press release (2011-07-26). [http://echl.com/stingrays-name-carbery-sixth-head-coach-in-team-history-p171936 "Stingrays name Carbery sixth head coach in team history"]. [[ECHL]]. Retrieved 2011-07-26. In a break with recent practice, the team selected a new assistant coach from outside the organization. [[J.B. Bittner]], previously an assistant coach for [[Ohio State University]]'s ice hockey team as well as a former professional player, joined the team in September 2011.{{cite news | last = Press release | title = Stingrays name Bittner as assistant coach | publisher = [[ECHL]] | date = September 19, 2011 | url = http://echl.com/URLstingrays-name-bittner-as-assistant-coach-p172731 | accessdate = September 20, 2011}} The team also faced some controversy when it was revealed that fan favorite and veteran enforcer [[Nate Kiser]] would not be returning to the Stingrays for the 2011–12 season. Kiser had not been offered a contract for the season and subsequently announced his retirement from professional hockey.{{cite news | title = Future Stingrays' hall of famer reflects on career | publisher = [[WCIV]] | date = October 3, 2011 | url = http://www.abcnews4.com/story/15608629/future-stingrays-hall-of-famer-reflects-on-career?autoStart=true&topVideoCatNo=default&clipId=6314476 | archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/62BwodM5C | archivedate = October 4, 2011}} To honor his contributions to the team over his seven-year career, the organization announced that Kiser would be inducted into the team's Hall of Fame on October 14, 2011, the opening night for the 2011–12 season.{{cite news | last = Press release | title = Nate Kiser to enter Stingrays Hall of Fame on opening night | publisher = Oursportscentral.com | date = October 2, 2011 | url = http://www.oursportscentral.com/services/releases/?id=4301860 | accessdate = October 2, 2011}} ==Team culture== [[File:ECHL-Uniform-SC.png|thumb|right|alt=Current Stingrays home and away jerseys.|Current Stingrays home (white) and away (blue) jerseys, adopted in [[2008–09 ECHL season|2008]]]] ===Logos=== The team's primary logo has evolved over the years. Beginning as a realistic rendition of a [[stingray]], it transitioned through a cartoon-style representation before settling on the [[:File:South Carolina Stingrays Logo.svg|stylized version]] used today. The [[Flag of South Carolina|state flag]] of [[South Carolina]] was originally used as the secondary logo (worn on the jersey shoulders). It has since been replaced by a variety of logos representing team affiliation, anniversary celebrations, and team championships. The current secondary logo (worn on home jerseys) returns to its origins as a rendition of the state flag, while the tertiary logo (worn on away jerseys) gives tribute to the [[Charleston, South Carolina|Charleston]] area with its representation of the [[Arthur Ravenel Jr. Bridge|Ravenel Bridge]].Press release (2008-06-04). [http://stingrayshockey.com/news/teamnews/index.html?article_id=703 "Stingrays, North Charleston Coliseum Extend Lease; Team Unveils New Logo"]. South Carolina Stingrays. Retrieved 2011-07-26. [[File:Cool-Ray.jpg|thumb|left|alt=South Carolina Stingrays mascot Cool Ray wearing a military themed jersey and a patriotic top hat.|Cool Ray entertains fans during the Stingrays' Military Appreciation Night.]] ===Mascot=== The organization's [[mascot]] is Cool Ray, a stingray that currently resembles the previous Stingrays logo used from 2000–08.Minis, Wevonneda (1995-10-29). [http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch95/1095/arc1029115346.shtml "Mascots pull in the business"]. ''[[Post and Courier]]''. Retrieved 2011-07-26.Miller, Andrew (2000-05-31). [http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch00/0500/arc0531258561.shtml "Stingrays unveil meaner, leaner look for 'Cool Ray'"]. ''[[Post and Courier]]''. Retrieved 2011-07-26. Alongside the [[#Current season roster|players]], Cool Ray serves as the organization's [[ambassador]] to the [[Charleston â North Charleston â Summerville metropolitan area|local community]], often appearing at [[Charleston County School District|local schools]], athletic competitions and [[Charitable organization|charity]] events.Shumake, Janice (1995-04-20). [http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch95/0495/arc0420104702.shtml "Dash to benefit humane society"]. ''[[Post and Courier]]''. Retrieved 2011-07-26.Mays, Dierdre (1995-06-22). [http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch95/0695/arc0622108519.shtml "Auto engines to whine in fund-raiser race"]. ''[[Post and Courier]]''. Retrieved 2011-07-26.Danzell, Lindsey (2005-02-24). [http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch05/0205/arc02242173852.shtml "KidsFair to feature fun, educational events"]. ''[[Post and Courier]]''. Retrieved 2011-07-26. Cool Ray also provides entertainment and [[comic relief]] on ice and in the stands during games, and serves as the Stingrays' Kids Club mascot. Additional mascots have included Little Puck, an [[anthropomorphism|anthropomorphic]] [[Puck (sports)#In ice hockey|hockey puck]] who partnered with Cool Ray from 1993 to 2008, and Excalibear, the Carolina Ice Palace's mascot, who joined Cool Ray for the 2010–2011 season. ===Media=== The Stingrays are covered by multiple [[media outlets]]. The ''[[Post and Courier]]'' provides [[newspaper]] coverage for the team. The team was was covered by sports reporters Keith Namm and Gene Sapakoff from 1993–98. Andrew Miller currently reports on the Stingrays and also authors a [[blog]] entitled "Rays the Roof," where he provides [[opinion pieces]] on the team's performance and transactions.Miller, Andrew (2008-03-13). [http://www.postandcourier.com/weblogs/stingrays/2008/mar/13/StingraysBlog/ "Rays looking for 2nd Place in South Division"]. ''[[Post and Courier]]''. Retrieved 2011-07-26. [[Television coverage]] of Stingrays games is provided over the [[internet]] on a [[pay-per-view]] basis by B2 Networks, a subsidiary of [[America One]] Broadcasting.Press release (2008-04-10). [http://stingrayshockey.com/news/teamnews/index.html?article_id=651 "B2 Networks Introduces New Technology"]. South Carolina Stingrays. Retrieved 2011-07-26. [[Play-by-play]] radio coverage of the Stingrays is handled by Joseph Zakrzewski, the organization's media specialist and broadcaster, who joined the Stingrays in 2009.Press release (2009-09-08). [http://stingrayshockey.com/news/teamnews/index.html?article_id=1110 "Stingrays Hire New Voice of the Rays"]. South Carolina Stingrays. Retrieved 2011-07-26. This coverage is available over the internet via the team's website, and on the air via the following [[AM radio]] stations: [[WTMZ]] 910 AM ([[ESPN Radio]]), [[WJKB]] 950 AM, [[WQSC]] 1340 AM, and [[WQNT]] 1450 AM ([[Fox Sports Radio]]).{{cite web |url=http://stingrayshockey.com/schedule/radioschedule/ |title=Stingrays Radio Schedule |publisher=South Carolina Stingrays |archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/60TLu0mxg |archivedate = 2011-07-26 |accessdate=2011-07-26}} The Stingrays maintain a strong online presence, utilizing social media outlets such as [[Facebook]] and [[Twitter]] to engage with fans. Video clips of team commercials and interviews are made available via "Stingrays TV," the Stingrays' [[YouTube]] channel.Press release (2009-10-22). [http://stingrayshockey.com/news/teamnews/index.html?article_id=1169 "Stingrays Launch New Website"]. South Carolina Stingrays. Retrieved 2011-07-26. ===Community Service=== [[File:Pink-in-the-Rink.jpg|thumb|right|alt=South Carolina Stingrays (in pink jerseys) battle the Toledo Walleye (in white jerseys) for control of the puck in front of the Walleye goaltender. The ice is dyed pink for Pink in the Rink 2010.|The Stingrays battle in front of the [[Toledo Walleye]] goal at Pink in the Rink 2010.]] The Stingrays organization honors the legacy of former owner [[Jerry Zucker (businessman)|Jerry Zucker]] by taking an active role in supporting local charities, to include the [[Medical University of South Carolina|MUSC]] Children's Hospital, [[Ronald McDonald House]], and Hockey Players for Kids, an organization supporting local youth hockey, among others. Player involvement includes celebrity bartender events to raise donations for charity, autographed equipment auctions, and visiting and playing with hospitalized children.Press release (2010-12-20). [http://www.stingrayshockey.com/team/teamnews/index.html?article_id=1625 "Stingrays Bring Holiday Cheer to MUSC Children's Hospital"]. South Carolina Stingrays. Retrieved 2011-07-26. The crowning event of the Stingrays season is the annual "Pink in the Rink" night, supporting [[Susan G. Komen for the Cure]] and the fight against [[breast cancer]]. Proceeds from ticket sales, vendor tables, and live and silent auctions featuring sports memorabilia including the actual game-used hockey sticks and jerseys were presented to the Lowcountry chapter of Susan G. Komen for the Cure. Pink in the Rink 2009 raised over $20,000, while the 2010 event raised over $40,000.Press release (2010-03-16). [http://www.stingrayshockey.com/news/teamnews/index.html?article_id=1406 "Stingrays' Pink in the Rink raises over $40,000"]. South Carolina Stingrays. Retrieved 2011-04-11. The 2011 Pink in the Rink game raised over $46,000, bringing the team's total donations since the event's inception in 2006 to more than $119,000.Press release (2011-03-02). [http://www.stingrayshockey.com/news/teamnews/index.html?article_id=1741 "Fifth Annual Pink in the Rink raises over $46,000"]. South Carolina Stingrays. Retrieved 2011-04-11. In honor of Jerry Zucker's contributions to the team and the local community, the Stingrays created the Jerry Zucker Community Service Award, to be presented yearly to the Stingrays player whose impact on the local community was greatest. Past awardees include [[Spencer Carbery]] (2008–09), [[Matt Scherer]] (2009–10) and [[Jordan Pietrus]] (2010–11).[http://www.stingrayshockey.com/team/history/ "History of the Stingrays"].
